description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old French conceder, from Latin concēdō (“give way, yield”), from con- (“wholly”) + cēdō (“to yield, give way, to go, grant”), from Proto-Indo-European *ked- (“to go, yield”).

verbs.description: concede (third-person singular simple present concedes, present participle conceding, simple past and past participle conceded)

entries.meaning: To yield or suffer; to surrender; to grant
examples: I have to concede the argument.
He conceded the race once it was clear he could not win.
Kendall conceded defeat once she realized she could not win in a battle of wits.

entries.meaning: To grant, as a right or privilege; to make concession of.
To admit or agree to be true; to acknowledge.
(sports) To have a goal or point scored against
(cricket) (of a bowler) to have runs scored off of one's bowling.
